‚Äâ image: Mealworms in the lab view more Credit: University of Nottingham Mealworms need a minimum level of protein to grow and become a sustainable food source, according to a new study¬†that challenges the myth that insects have superpowers of taking plastic waste and converting it to a nutritionally valuable product. Nutritional scientists from the University of Nottingham have tested diets comprising protein and all other nutrients against those containing little and none, and found that whilst mealworms could survive eating no protein they do need a minimum amount of protein to grow and pupate. Their findings have been published in the¬†Journal of Insects as Food and Feed. The larvae of the beetle Tenebrio molitor (yellow mealworms) were studied,¬†the insect's main components are protein, fat and fibre giving them high¬†nutritional value, and the potential to be a sustainable alternative protein source, which is likely to be as animal feed but is also being explored as a possible¬†sustainable food source for humans. These mealworms have the versatility of being able to grow on relatively low quality food sources, such as wheat bran and other cereals as well as industry by-products such as distiller's grains and garden and vegetable waste. Recent research has also shown certain types of¬†mealworm can be fed on polystyrene. This new research shows that this is not enough to produce the levels of growth and nutrition required to provide a food source and that the crude protein and fat composition of mealworms varies considerably, dependent on the feed utilised. To prove that a minimum level of nutrition is required the teams fed groups of mealworms different diets containing varying amounts of nutritional components and protein. Mealworms fed the protein-free diets appeared to halt growth and didn't enter the pupation stage of their life-cycle which is vital for breeding. This casts considerable doubt of the value of substrates free of protein (such as plastics) as viable feed sources for commercial production of mealworms. John Brameld, Professor of Nutritional Chemistry at the University of Nottingham said: ‚ÄúOur research is focused on mealworms as an effective and sustainable alternative source of protein, and we are trying to find the optimum composition of nutrients to achieve this. This research is an important step towards that as we now know that despite what previous research has suggested, mealworms need all nutrients, including protein to be able to grow and pupate. Eating plastics alone or another non-protein diet does allow them to survive, but doesn't provide the nutrients needed for the mealworms to be used as food.‚Äù Tim Parr, Professor in Nutritional Biochemistry added: ‚ÄúUnderstanding the miniumum nutritional requirements for production animals such as mealworms is a vital part of being able to move towards using them at scale as a nutritious alternative food source. We now have that baseline and know that protein is a key requirement, so we can build on this with further work to fine tune the nutritional density and quantities of feed until we find a formula that is optimal for growth of the mealworm and delivery of key nutrients in a way that is is cost effective and sustainable.‚Äù

‚Äâ This is gonna be a long answer, strap in. Here is everything I wish I'd been told when I started out. Your pellet choices are probably the best out there, so that's a good start! For feeding quantities, I would recommend getting a set of mini scales from amazon for weighing small quantities, you can (and should) weigh your birds every morning on these too. Start by giving them about 1 tbsp each of veg for breakfast and pellets for dinner, and fine tune how much you give them based on how much they eat. The pellets, tops especially, turn to powder pretty quick, but don't worry, the powder is perfectly edible too, you can leave it in (not overnight or they will probably eat that in the morning instead of chop). All birds will have different appetites, so I can't give a one size fits all answer, your best tool for how much to feed will be keeping track of the ratios of veg:pellets:nuts/seeds. There are a lot of different answers on what the ideal ratio is, I'd say a minimum of 40% veg (by weight), my tiel is pretty healthy on 50/50 breakfast/dinner, + extra bits and bobs for foraging, but every now and then he just isn't felling the veggies and leaves most of it, you don't wanna panic unless they're consistently leaving the food they normally eat. You want no more than 10-15% nuts and seeds, I weigh him a little treat portion every morning, but you can eyeball it once you know roughly what it looks like. Spike is pretty small for a cockatiel, he only eats about 6 grams of food a day. I'd also recommend buying some different whole grains (oat, wheat, rye, spelt, etc) and making a little grain mix, super healthy and good for training or foraging. The key to nutrition is diversity, as many different ingredients in little jars clogging up your cupboards as you can reasonably get, and lots of different colours and types of veggies in the chop. Stick to human grade ingredients as much as possible. If the birds are fussy with the veg to begin with, I find mixing it with a bit of steamed and mashed sweet potato works wonders for getting them to try new things. I make a dry mix for his dinner, which is pellets, whole grains, herbs, flowers, and freeze dried sprouted legumes + seeds, and some freeze dried veggies too. It has taken a LONG time to convince him half this food is edible, so keep offering new healthy things and don't give up. You will have to do some observing and fine tuning based on their specific needs, just keep adjusting until you find what maintains them at an ideal weight. For in the cage, yours already looks better than a lot of the first setups you see on here, so props to you for that. Basically, you want as many different branch widths and textures of perches you can fit, for optimum foot health. Avoid dowels, they're slippery, too consistent in width, and in my opinion, boring and a waste of potential in a setup. Adding some perches lower down, maybe a rope that leads down to the floor, will encourage them to explore and be more active. Cockatiels also like to find snacks off the floor, they do a lot of ground feeding in the wild, unlike a lot of other parrots. And if you catch them chewing up that cotton rope perch, or any other cotton they may have access too, take it out and replace it with something like sisal, jute, or hemp. Cotton, if injested, can cause dangerous crop impactions, and no one wants to send their precious baby in for surgery. Stuff attached to the outside of the cage and stands around the room/house will do wonders for their confidence in this strange new environment. If you can where you live, hang swings from the ceiling too, they'll love it. You can help them explore by training them to follow a finger, touch a target stick, or go where you point. In terms of toys, there are a few good destructible materials that are great for small birds: sola, mahogany pods, cork (spike's favourite), dried palm leaf, and balsa wood, often sold as kabobs and kabob chips. Buying loose parts and making your own is fun! If they don't know what to do with these things, you can train them to rip things up, which is also fun. A lot of bird toys are made to look good to people, but are no fun for birds. You want to look for things they can rip up, and things you can hide snacks in. The solid hard wood toys, plastic toys, mirrors, and bells are not what you want. There are some brilliant YouTube channels I've gotten a lot of my info from: BirdTricks, excellent content on training and behaviour, and BirdNerdSophie + the parrot teacher, a duo that focuses more on small birds with some great stuff on diet, foraging, and enrichment. Definitely look up foraging ideas, teaching my two how to forage, slowly making it harder and more complex, and watching their little bird brains working is so rewarding, and it keeps them happy too. It's just Spike now, and he gets his dinner in foraging activities every day, if he didn't he'd eat it in 5 seconds and then spend the next hour yelling at me. Some excellent starting materials for foraging are crinkly paper, wooden blocks to push about, and tissue paper for making little food parcels to hunt down (very cute). Most importantly, stay calm, take it at your own pace, don't get overwhelmed at the absolute wall of information I've just given you, be creative, and have fun! Parrots are difficult, complicated, and infuriating at times, but they are absolutely wonderful and I hope you can fill each other's lives with joy. Good luck!
